title: How to Clean a Road Bike

steps.headline: Clean the bike chain with a degreaser.
steps.description: Before lubricating your bike chain, get the old dirty grease off with a chain degreaser, which you can buy at a bike shop. Depending on the type of degreaser you have, you may have to spray it on or paint it on. Spin the pedal backwards with one hand as you apply the degreaser to the chain with the other. Make sure that the chain moves all the way through a full rotation so that you can clean the whole chain. It’s a good idea to wear gloves to protect your hands while using a degreaser. If your chain slips off while you’re cleaning it, just put it back on.

steps.headline: Lubricate the chain once it’s degreased.
steps.description: You can buy bike chain lubricant at any bike shop or online. It’s best to buy the kind that squeezes out of the bottle, rather than the spray kind, so that you can really control which parts of your bike it touches. Hold the bottle above the bottom of the chain and squeeze out a thin stream. With your other hand, spin the pedal backwards so that the chain moves through the chain rings. Run the chain around a few times after you have finished applying the lubricant. Use “wet lube” if you regularly bike in poor weather conditions, and “dry lube” for sunny conditions. You don’t need to take the chain off your bike to clean it. Wipe off any excess lubricant from your chain with a rag.

steps.headline: Wipe off the bike frame with hot, soapy water.
steps.description: Fill a bucket with hot water and add a bike soap or household dish soap. Use a sponge or a rag to clean off the frame. Start at the top of the bike frame and work your way down, so that you don’t drip muddy water and freshly cleaned parts of your bike. Keep dipping your sponge in the water so that you don’t spread dirt from one part of the bike to another.

parts.name: Removing the Wheels and Washing Thoroughly

steps.headline: Disengage the brakes so that you can take off the wheels.
steps.description: If you have a caliper rim brake, pull up the quick-release lever so that the brakes aren’t gripping your wheel. The release could also be a button on the brake lever. Disconnect cantilever brakes by squeezing the calipers together and disconnecting the brake cable. If you have disk brakes, you don’t need to disengage the pads. If you can’t figure out how to release your brakes, try looking up the type of bike you have online.

steps.headline: Remove the wheels with a quick-release lever or wrench.
steps.description: Many bikes make it easy to remove the wheels by having a quick-release lever at the hub, or center, of the wheel. Just pull up the lever and remove the tire. If there’s no quick release lever because your wheels are held on with axle nuts, you’ll have to remove the nuts with a wrench. If you are unsure how to remove your bike wheel, look up your specific brand of bike online for an instruction manual.

steps.headline: Prop up the frame in a stand or against a wall.
steps.description: If you regularly bike and do your own maintenance, it’s probably worth it to buy a bike stand at a bike shop. However, you can also prop your bike up against a wall or even upside down. Keeping your bike in a stand or against a wall keeps it cleaner.

steps.headline: Give the frame another scrub now that the wheels are off.
steps.description: You’ll have access to more parts of the frame once the wheels are off. Go over the parts you’ve already washed, and the newly accessible parts of the frame with your sponge and the hot, soapy water. If your water is getting muddy, pour it down the sink and prepare a fresh bucket of hot, soapy water.

steps.headline: Sponge the outside of the tires and the spokes.
steps.description: Sponge off the outsides of your tires carefully, along both rims and around the perimeter. Since tires are what directly touches the ground, they’ll probably be pretty filthy, so make sure you are frequently washing off your sponge. Clean the spokes off, because they get spattered as you ride.

steps.headline: Clean the hubs and chain rings with a stiff bristled brush.
steps.description: The hubs are the parts in the middle of the wheel where the spokes meet, and the chain rings are those metal circles on your back wheel that hold the chain. Scrub the hubs and chain rings with a stiff-bristled brush before sponging them off. An old toothbrush is a good substitute if you don’t have a cleaning brush.

steps.headline: Put your bike back together.
steps.description: Reattach the wheels onto your bike by lining them up in the frame and either pushing the quick-release lever back down or fastening them in with nuts and a wrench. Make sure that your wheel is straight and centered before you fasten it in place. Put the chain back on the chain rings and reengage the brakes. Spin the pedals a few times to make sure everything is connected properly. Squeeze the brakes to make sure you reengaged them properly.

steps.headline: Hose off your bike gently with clean water.
steps.description: Your bike is now clean but covered in soap, so you’re going to have to hose it off. You’re not power washing it, so there’s no need to blast the water pressure. If you don’t have a hose, you can get a bucket of clean water and sponge off your bike, which will take a little longer.

steps.headline: Dry your bike off with a rag and let the bike dry in a warm place.
steps.description: Wipe down your bike with a rag to make sure that most of the water is off. Before you store your bike though, it has to be completely dry, so leave it someplace warm to dry. If it’s winter and you normally store your bike outside, you’re going to have to put up with a bike in your room for a bit. Now your bike is clean and ready to ride!
